title: 103_hr5089
content: The Act titled "Individual Training Account Act of 1994" introduces Individual Training Accounts under section 220 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Individuals can deduct cash payments made to an individual training account, with a maximum deduction of $2,000 or the excess of $6,000 over the previous year's account balance. No deduction is allowed before the beneficiary reaches age 18. An individual training account is established for individuals under 18 for qualified expenses. The account must meet specific requirements for contributions. An individual training account is established for individuals under 18 for qualified expenses. The trustee must be a bank or a person approved by the Secretary, assets cannot be invested in life insurance contracts, the individual's interest must be nonforfeitable, and assets cannot be commingled except in specific funds. Qualified expenses include specific categories. The individual training account for individuals under 18 covers qualified expenses such as job training and job-related relocation expenses. Job training expenses include tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for courses at an eligible educational institution or training program. The term 'eligible educational institution' refers to an institution of higher education or a vocational school. An institution of higher education includes those described in the Higher Education Act of 1965. A reasonable allowance for meals and lodging is also provided while attending such institutions or training programs. The term 'vocational school' refers to an area vocational education school as defined in the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Applied Technology Education Act. An 'applicable training program' includes programs defined in the Job Training Partnership Act and those approved under the Trade Act of 1974. Deduction for amounts paid from an account is denied. Distributions from individual training accounts are included in gross income unless used exclusively for qualified expenses in the same taxable year. Such expenses cannot be deducted under certain provisions. Excess contributions to individual training accounts can be distributed before the tax return due date if they exceed the allowable deduction amount, are not deducted, and include the net income from the excess contribution. Excess contributions to individual training accounts can be distributed before the tax return due date if they exceed the allowable deduction amount, are not deducted, and include the net income from the excess contribution. Rollovers of amounts from one individual training account to another for the same individual must be completed within 60 days to avoid taxation under this subtitle. Individual training accounts are exempt from taxation unless they cease to be such accounts due to prohibited transactions. In such cases, the account will lose its exemption and be subject to taxes on unrelated business income. Individual training accounts lose their tax exemption if they cease to be such accounts due to prohibited transactions. In that case, the account is treated as distributing all its assets, and if the account is used as security for a loan, that portion is affected. If an individual uses any portion of their training account as security for a loan, that portion is treated as distributed and not used for qualified expenses. An additional tax of 10 percent is imposed on the amount included in gross income if the distribution is not used for qualified expenses. If an individual's training account distribution is treated as income due to specific circumstances, a 10 percent tax increase applies. Exceptions exist for disability, death, or distributions after age 59 1/2. The section discusses the rules regarding individual training accounts, including exceptions for distributions after age 59 1/2 and the treatment of custodial accounts as trusts. Community property laws are not considered in the application of this section. The trustee of an individual training account must report account activities to the Secretary and the account holder. A deduction for individual training accounts is allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income. The tax on excess contributions to individual training accounts is amended under section 4973 of the Code. This includes adding individual training accounts to the heading of the section and defining them within the context of the Code. For individual training accounts, excess contributions are defined as the amount exceeding the allowable deduction under section 220. Any distributed contribution under section 220(d)(2) is treated as not contributed. Additionally, individuals with individual training accounts are exempt from the tax on prohibited transactions under section 4975. The text discusses amendments to the tax code regarding individual training accounts. It includes changes related to transactions, failure to provide reports, and the filing of reports for individual training accounts. The text discusses penalties for failure to file a report regarding individual training accounts under section 220(i) of the tax code. Clerical amendments are also made to the table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1. The text amends sections 4973 and 6693 of the tax code related to penalties for excess contributions to individual retirement accounts and individual training accounts. The amendments made by this section apply to contributions for taxable years starting after December 31, 1994.
